69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:31): you're not missing anything
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:31): (from the whatwg perspective anyway)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:33): can someone teach me what a singular transform matrix's implications are?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:34): wikipedia's math pages are inpenetrable
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:35): A simular matrix doesn't have an inverse, so I guess once loses information e.g. by mapping points from an area onto a line
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:36): doesn't know if that is helpful

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:36): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, it has derivative zero.  It's not invertible.  Geometrically, it multiplies areas by zero, so in two dimensions, it maps planes to points or lines.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:36): Anything specific you want to know?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:37): Singular vs. invertible is one of the basic differences you can have with matrices, so there are tons of things to say about it.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:37): if you have a plane and your transform it by a singular matrix, where is the resulting point or line?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:38): i guess it's got zero thickness so it doesn't matter
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:38): i'm trying to work out why browsers can't just implement the spec with singular matrices, instead needing some special text for them

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:38): If it's a regular 2x2 matrix, it will map the plane to either the origin or a line through the origin.  If it's an augmented matrix, it transforms affinely instead of linearly, so the point or line can be anywhere.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:39): What exactly constitutes "singular" when your matrix's values are floating-points is nonobvious.
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:39): by derivative, 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 meant determinant
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:39): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: yeah that's why i was hoping there'd be a nice way to not answer the question
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:39): So I did.  How embarrasing.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:39): embarrassing.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:40): Anyway, your questions have veered into the highly practical, so I don't think my expertise will be of much use.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:40): hah
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:40): I think it really depends on the wording of the spec whether it needs to make a special case for singular matrices
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:41): likewise for code
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:41): but there are some things where it's certainly unavoidable
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:41): like if we add an API for getting "coordinates in the space of element A" to "... of element B"

104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:42): if there's a singular transform between them, then there's no answer to the question in one direction (except for a narrow set of points) and lots of answers the other way

104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:43): likewise, there are a bunch of algorithms that have a "divide by the determinant" step, which doesn't work so well when it's 0.  Usually such algorithms don't make any sense to apply to singular transforms anyway.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:43): yeah
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:43): but the spec still needs to say what it does (return 0, throw exception, etc.)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:44): well luckily for me i don't think i have anything that returns points or divides anything by anything
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:44): however
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:44): people have nonetheless asked the question

104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:44): (e.g., when animating transforms, the fallback case is to decompose the matrix and animate the pieces -- and the decomposition algorithm doesn't work on singular matrices)
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:45): asked the question about what?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:45): "what should happen if you have a singular transformation matrix"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:46): e.g. if you call c.scale(0,1); and then c.fill(); with a path
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:46): ah, so these are questions about canvas
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:46): I think that's easy: nothing.
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:48): though if the path was set *before* the scale...?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:48): the path is non-zero
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:48): (does the scale affect it?)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:48): the fill is all that is scaled
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:48): hmmm, I don't remember canvas well enough to discuss this intelligently
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (00:49): istm the canvas spec should align with the 2d/3d css transforms specs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:50): if img1 is a mostly green image, in webkit, this is a mostly green rectangle:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:50): c.beginPath(); c.rect(100,100,100,100); c.fillStyle = c.createPattern(img1, 'repeat');
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:50): c.fill();
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:50): but if i add one "0" to that number, it no longer paints anything.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:51): because repeating a zero-width image across the plane doesn't make much sense
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:51): but what about if the fill is a color?
bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc (00:52): if it does nothing, does the globalCompositeOperation still apply?
bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc (00:52): if i do c.globalCompositeOperation="copy"; c.scale(0,1); makePath(c); c.fill();
bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc (00:52): is my canvas now empty?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:53): not in webkit
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:53): however

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:53): If we had perfect precision, all this stuff would be well-defined.  But some things suddenly behave differently at determinant zero compared to determinant epsilon, and there's no difference with floating-point . . .

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:53): I think the reason the spec doesn't return points or divide anything by anything is that it doesn't actually define the algorithms to render things (which can do those things)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:54): then it is empty
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:55): that is, c.scale(1e-36,1);, c.scale(1e-37,1); and c.scale(0,1);
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:55): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: yeah, i was just noticing that nothing actually says how fill() paints a repeating pattern
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:55): Sound like FLT_MIN

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:15): they measure it in "GB-months", which I think means to multiply by the amount of time, eg. 2 GB for two weeks is one GB-month
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:16): (don't use a petabyte of storage and blame me for the billing if I'm wrong, though)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:17): that sounds equivalent to saying that they average the disk usage over each month
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:18): i regularly create large temporary volumes for things and delete them after a day or two; i'm sure they don't take the maximum or anything like that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:20): i wonder how often they sample
